Dear Ms. Taylor:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204 - 6992.

Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Education
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4123
Section (2) Provision shall be made for an appropriate education program
Description in accordance with 1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to 380.1853. Each
resident of school age shall be enrolled not later than 5 school
days after admission and continuously thereafter.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Beginning 10/01/2024, youth were routinely denied the ability to
attend school.
Investigation Therapist was interviewed via telephone on October 28, 2024,
and reported they had no further information.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Supervisor 1 reported youth are refusing to go
to school but generally it is more than one youth in the unit who
will refuse. Supervisor 1 stated staff are reading a book out loud,
turning the lights on, writing incident reports on the youth who are
refusing and encouraging the youth to attend school but still some
youth refuse.
Case Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Case Manager described if one youth in a unit
refuses to attend school, and the other youth want to attend there
are occasional times where the youth who want to attend school
cannot attend because of a lack of staff. Case Manager stated
staff must stay in the unit with the youth so there is not staff to sit
in the classroom. Case Manager described some youth pick and
choose when to attend school and will refuse to get out of bed in
the morning to attend school. Case Manager reported workers
are being notified.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Youth A stated he goes to school “almost
every day.” Youth A reported he could not recall the last time he
was not able to go to school because of ratio but stated he
thought it was last week (October 21 -25). Youth A stated he
could not recall how many times he has not been able to attend
school because of ratio but reported it has occurred more than
one time.
2

Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Youth B reported he attends school “most
days” but other days he does not want to attend school so does
not go. Youth B stated staff try and talk him into attending school,
if he still refuses, he gets an IR (incident report) and cannot attend
any fun outing.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Youth C stated he tries to attend school every
day but sometimes he is too sleepy. Youth C described being the
only youth currently in his unit. Youth C reported if he refuses to
go to school, he gets an IR. Youth C reported there have been
times he has not been able to attend school because there were
not enough staff to sit in the classroom and sit in the unit with
youth who refused to attend school.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Youth D reported he attends school about
three days a week. Youth D described there are times he “doesn’t
feel like going” and times he cannot attend because of ratio.
Youth D stated if he refuses to attend school, staff talk to him and
tell him he needs to attend and if he still refuses to attend, he gets
an IR.
Youth D reported he has been “shoved” by staff causing him to
lose balance when trying to walk out of the unit door. Youth D
stated if he gets out the unit door staff will “yank” him back into the
unit. Youth D denied getting injured. This is being investigated in
special investigation 2025SIC0000068.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Supervisor 2 reported it does not happen too
often, but it has occurred occasionally where youth are not able to
attend school because there are not enough staff to sit in the
classroom and sit in the unit(s) with the youth who refuse to attend
school. Supervisor 2 stated when this occurs every effort is made
to find staff to sit in the classroom or encourage the youth who
refuse to attend school to attend school so the entire unit can
attend school. Supervisor 2 described if a youth refuses to attend
school staff provides multiple redirections, the youth will earn an
IR for disruption of program, and the youth’s worker is notified.
Teacher was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Teacher reported staff must sit in the
classrooms with youth because the teachers cannot provide line
of sight. Teacher described being aware youth are refusing to
3

attend school and the facility does not have enough staff to stay in
the unit with the youth refusing to attend school and have staff sit
in the classrooms with the youth who want to attend school.
Teacher denied this being the only reason youth are not attending
school. Teacher described youth as manipulating the system to
attend some classes but not other classes. Teacher stated many
times youth are not coming to school in the morning. Teacher
reported youth are not coming to school because there is no
accountability from the youths’ workers, or the State and staff
cannot force the youth to attend school. Teacher stated he emails
the workers to notify them their youth are not attending school, but
nothing is done to hold the youth accountable by the worker
and/or court.
Director was interviewed via telephone on October 29, 2024.
Director reported it was brought to her attention by Therapist
youth were not attending school because of staff ratio and
because some youths were refusing. Director stated she spoke
with Therapist about addressing it therapeutically with the youth
who were refusing to attend school.
Director described talking with Teacher on October 23 or October
24, 2024 about coming into the units where youth are refusing to
attend school and reading a book/teaching in the unit. Director
stated she sent a text message to all staff directing staff to turn on
the lights and read loudly from a book when youth are refusing to
attend school so perhaps the youth will change their mind and go
to school. Director stated staff are encouraging youth to attend
school, writing IRs and notifying workers. Director reported she
spoke with Case Manager to ensure probation officers are being
pulled in as well as the youths’ parents or family support system
so everyone can encourage the youth to attend school. Director
described Licensee Designee, Vice President of Residential
Programs, and herself met with every unit on October 22, 2024, to
discuss the importance of education, expectations of the program
and attending school.
Superintendent was interviewed via telephone on November
13, 2024. Superintendent expressed concerns with youth not
attending school because the facility does not have enough staff,
youth not being supervised, fire extinguishers missing, and doors
being screwed shut from the exterior of the building (being
investigated in special investigations 2025SIC0000104 and
2025SIC0000105).
Documents Reviewed:
4

• Text screen shot sent by Director to all staff on 10/25/2024
at 5:57am, stating if youth refuse to attend school, staff are
to grab a book and read as loud as they can. The text
message indicated Youth A and Youth E want to go to
school but Youth D will not get up for them [Youth A and
Youth E] to go.
• Email exchanges from Therapist to Vice President of
Residential Programs and Director dated 10/17/2024 and
10/18/2024 discussing youth refusing to attend school and
how that can affect youth in the unit who want to attend
school not being able to go because of ratio. Emails
indicate Therapist sat in the classroom on 10/18/24 with
youth who wanted to attend school while staff stayed in the
unit with the youth who refused to attend school. Director
forwarded email with concern to Case Manager on
10/17/2024 asking him to reach out to probation officers for
a violation for not attending school and to go to the units
each morning to help get the youth to school.
• Student data sheet from August 1 – October 28, 2024.
Data documents percentage of absences for Youth A at
46.2%, Youth B 86.5%, Youth C 85.6%, and Youth D at
91.3%.
• Assessment Procedures Policy/program statement
documents, residential program ensures that client’s
individual needs are met in addition to standard educational
topics and requirements.
• Clarence Fischer Center Program Statement documents,
“The program emphasizes appropriate social, life, and
interpersonal skills development. Individualized treatment
planning and counseling, as well as individualized
educational planning, allows each male to work to his own
emotional and developmental capacity.” Additional
services listed by the facility are, “small and highly
structured classrooms which include academic
assessments, transferable high school credits, GED
preparation and testing.”
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as per teacher, youth, and
staff interviews along with reviewing student data sheets
provisions are not being made for youth to continuously attend
school.
Conclusion Violation Established
5

Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The school requires staff to attend school, and they did not have
sufficient staffing resources to provide. If one youth refused to go
to school, none of the youth were able to attend due to staffing
issues.
Investigation Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Supervisor 1 described it does happen
occasionally where youth do not attend school because staff must
stay in the unit with the youth who are refusing to attend school,
making it so none of the youth in the unit attend school.
Supervisor 1 reported staff must be in the classroom with youth to
provide line of sight, as the teachers are not allowed to provide
line of sight.
Case Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Case Manager stated the facility is limited on
staff, so youth are not going to school. Case Manager described if
one youth in a unit refuses to attend school, and the other youth
want to attend there are occasional times where the youth who
want to attend school cannot attend because of a lack of staff.
Case Manager stated staff must stay in the unit with the youth so
there is not staff to sit in the classroom.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Youth A reported there have been times he
has not been able to go to school because a youth in his unit has
refused to attend school so every youth in the unit must stay back
from school because of staff ratio. Youth A explained staff must
stay in the unit to watch the youth who is refusing to attend school,
making it so the staff is not available to go to the classroom with
the youth who want to attend school. Youth A stated a supervisor
usually finds a way for the youth who want to attend school, to
attend school. Youth A stated he goes to school “almost every
day.” Youth A reported he could not recall the last time he was
not able to go to school because of ratio but stated he thought it
was last week (October 21 -25). Youth A stated he could not
6

recall how many times he has not been able to attend school
because of ratio but reported it has occurred more than one time.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Youth B described if he does not attend
school the other youth in the unit will not be able to attend
because of “staff ratio.” Youth B explained staff must stay with
him in the unit so then the staff cannot sit in the classroom with
the youth who want to attend school. Youth B reported staff try
and find another staff member who can sit in the classroom but
sometimes there are not extra staff available. Youth B stated he
could not recall how many times this has occurred but stated it
was more than once.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Youth C reported there have been times he
has not been able to attend school because there were not
enough staff to sit in the classroom and sit in the unit with youth
who refused to attend school. Youth C stated this occurred when
he was in unit 3 and unit 4 with multiple youth about two or three
weeks ago. Youth C reported there have been several times he
could not attend school because there were not enough staff.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Youth D described there are times he “doesn’t
feel like going” and times he cannot attend because of ratio.
Youth D reported he is currently in a unit with two other youth.
Youth D described if a youth refuses to attend school, and another
staff cannot be found to sit in the classroom then the whole unit
cannot attend school. Youth D stated he is not sure how often this
has occurred but reported it has occurred more than once.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Supervisor 2 reported it does not happen too
often, but it has occurred occasionally where youth are not able to
attend school because there are not enough staff to sit in the
classroom and sit in the unit(s) with the youth who refuse to attend
school. Supervisor 2 stated when this occurs every effort is made
to find staff to sit in the classroom or encourage the youth who
refuse to attend school to attend school so the entire unit can
attend school.
Teacher was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 29, 2024. Teacher reported staff must sit in the
classrooms with youth because the teachers cannot provide line
of sight. Teacher described being aware youth are refusing to
7

attend school and the facility does not have enough staff to stay in
the unit with the youth refusing to attend school and have staff sit
in the classrooms with the youth who want to attend school.
Director was interviewed via telephone on October 29, 2024.
Director reported there are times youth have not attended school
because of ratio but staff work to find an available staff to sit in the
classroom but that is not always possible. Director stated she is
not aware of this occurring very often, that the case manager or
therapist has been sitting in the classroom. Director described
units are being looked at to combine youth so there are enough
staff to stay with youth who refuse to attend school and staff to sit
in the classroom with youth who want to attend school.
Superintendent was interviewed via telephone on November
13, 2024. Superintendent expressed concerns with youth not
attending school because the facility does not have enough staff.
Documents Reviewed:
• Email exchanges from Therapist to Vice President of
Residential Programs and Director dated 10/17/2024 and
10/18/2024 discussing youth refusing to attend school and
how that can affect youth in the unit who want to attend
school not being able to go because of ratio. Emails
indicate Therapist sat in the classroom on 10/18/24 with
youth who wanted to attend school while staff stayed in the
unit with the youth who refused to attend school. Director
forwarded email with concern to Case Manager on
10/17/2024 asking him to reach out to probation officers for
a violation for not attending school and to go to the units
each morning to help get to the youth to school.
• Student data sheet from August 1 – October 28, 2024.
Data documents percentage of absences for Youth A at
46.2%, Youth B 86.5%, Youth C 85.6%, and Youth D at
91.3%.
• Clarence Fischer Center Program Statement documents,
“Staff to client ratio 1 staff to 2 clients awake time.”
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as per staff and youth
interviews, the facility did not have sufficient number staff on shift
in order to provide for the continual educational needs of the youth
as there were times youth were prevented from attending school
due to lack of staff.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2023C00000295 dated 06/05/2023; CAP approved 08/04/2023
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
